p.text: The District Court Act 1973 No 9 was assented to 10 April 1973 and commenced 1 July 1973. It has since been amended by:

heading.title: TRANSITIONAL INFORMATION — District Court (Procedure) Amendment Act 1984

p.text: Legislation cited in [18,000] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court (Procedure) Amendment Act 1984 (s 6), Schedules 3, 4.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 Part 3 , Part 4, s 113, section 172(2), s 173, s 2(2), s 32(2), s 32(2A), s 32(3) , s 69A, s 78(1).
(NSW) Crimes Act 1900 s 577.
The District Court (Procedure) Amendment Act 1984 contained transitional and other provisions relating to the District Court Act 1973. Schedule 9 of that Act provides as follows:
In this Schedule, an expression defined in the Principal Act has the same meaning as it has in that Act.

After the commencement of Schedules 3 and 4 [on 1 July 1985], no power conferred by any Act on the Judges, a majority of the Judges, any number of the Judges or a single Judge to make rules in respect of any particular matter shall be exercised otherwise than by the Rule Committee making rules under and in accordance with Part 3 of the Principal Act (as in force after that commencement) in the case of a civil matter, or under and in accordance with Part 4 of the Principal Act (as so in force) in the case of a criminal matter.

Any rules made under any power conferred on the Judges, a majority of the Judges, any number of the Judges or a single Judge by any Act (including the Principal Act) and in force immediately before the commencement of Schedule 3 , shall continue in force as if they had been made under Part 3 of the Principal Act (as in force after that commencement) and may from time to time be amended or revoked by the Rule Committee.

leg:heading.title: Proclamations under section 172 of the Principal Act to be continued in force

p.text: Any proclamation that was in force, or was deemed to be a proclamation, under section 172(2) of the Principal Act immediately before the commencement of Schedule 4 specifying the places at which the Court may sit in its criminal and special jurisdiction shall, after that commencement, be deemed to be a proclamation under section 172(2) of the Principal Act (as in force after that commencement) specifying the places at which the Court may sit in its criminal jurisdiction.

leg:heading.title: Proclamations under section 173 of the Principal Act deemed to be orders made by Chief Judge

p.text: Any proclamation that was in force under section 173 of the Principal Act immediately before the commencement of Schedule 4 specifying the places and times at which the Court shall sit in its criminal and special jurisdiction shall, after that commencement, be deemed to be a direction under section 173 of the Principal Act (as in force after that commencement) specifying the places and the appointed times at which the Court shall sit in its criminal jurisdiction.

leg:heading.title: Resolution of questions as to whether a matter is within the special civil jurisdiction or the criminal jurisdiction of the Court

p.text: If after the commencement of Schedules 3 and 4 a question arises as to whether or not any matter is within the special civil jurisdiction of the Court or its criminal jurisdiction, that question shall be determined as provided by rules made under clause 12.

leg:heading.title: Proceedings pending in the Court in the exercise of its criminal and special jurisdiction

p.text: Where any proceedings would, if Schedules 3 and 4 had not commenced, have been continued, heard or disposed of in the Court in its criminal and special jurisdiction, those proceedings shall, after the commencement of those Schedules, be continued, heard or disposed of:
in the case of criminal proceedings, in the Court in its criminal jurisdiction, or
in the case of any other proceedings which were in its criminal and special jurisdiction, in the Court in its special civil jurisdiction.
Nothing in subclause (1) affects the powers of the Supreme Court under section 577 of the Crimes Act 1900.

leg:heading.title: Directions as to sittings at proclaimed places

p.text: A direction given by the Governor under section 32(2) of the Principal Act (as in force immediately before the commencement of Schedule 3 ) shall, unless it has ceased to be in force before that commencement, continue in force as if it were a direction given under section 32(2A) of the Principal Act.

A direction given by the Chief Judge under section 32(3) of the Principal Act (as in force immediately before the commencement of Schedule 3 ) shall, unless it has ceased to be in force before that commencement, continue in force as if it were a direction given under section 32(3) of the Principal Act (as in force after that commencement) and as if the last mentioned provision had been in force at the time when the direction was given.

leg:heading.title: Power of Court to appoint expert witness

p.text: Section 69A of the Principal Act (as inserted by Schedule 3 ) applies to proceedings commenced, but not completed, before the commencement of that Schedule.

leg:heading.title: Cases in which jury may be summoned

p.text: The provisions of section 78(1) of the Principal Act (as in force before the commencement of Schedule 3 ) shall, notwithstanding the amendment to that subsection effected by that Schedule, continue to apply to proceedings commenced before that commencement, but only in relation to a party who has complied with the requirements of those provisions before that commencement.
Section 113 of the Principal Act (as amended by Schedule 3 ) applies to and in relation to an application made under that section, but not disposed of, before the commencement of that Schedule.
Where:
any provision of the Principal Act is repealed or amended by a provision of this Act, and

before the commencement of the repealing or amending provision, any judgment, ruling, order, direction or decision of the Court had been given or made under the first mentioned provision but had not been satisfied or discharged or had not otherwise ceased to have effect,

that judgment, ruling, order, direction or decision shall continue to have effect, and the first mentioned provision shall continue to have effect in relation to that judgment, ruling, order, direction or decision, as if the repealing or amending provision had not been enacted.
Where:
a provision of the Principal Act is repealed or amended by a provision of this Act, and

before the commencement of the repealing or amending provision, a document had been lodged or filed in the Court, or had been issued by or from the Court, under the first mentioned provision and had not ceased to have effect,

then, subject to the provisions of this Schedule, that document shall continue to have effect, and the first mentioned provision shall continue to have effect in relation to that document, as if the repealing or amending provision had not been enacted.

leg:heading.title: Power to make rules relating to matters of a savings or transitional nature

p.text: The Rule Committee may make rules containing provisions of a savings or transitional nature consequent on the enactment of this Act.
A provision made under subclause (1) may take effect as from the day appointed and notified under section 2(2) or a later day.
To the extent to which a provision referred to in subclause (1) takes effect from a date that is earlier than the date of its publication in the Gazette, the provision does not operate so as:
to affect, in a manner prejudicial to any person, the rights of that person before the date of that publication, or
to impose liabilities on any person in respect of anything done or omitted to be done before the date of that publication.
A provision made under subclause (1) shall, if the rules expressly so provide, have effect notwithstanding any of the preceding clauses of this Schedule.

An Act to establish a District Court of New South Wales; to provide for the appointment of, and the powers, authorities, duties and functions of, Judges and other officers of the Court; to empower the Court to hear and dispose of certain civil and criminal proceedings; to abolish the several District Courts and Courts of Quarter Sessions; to repeal the District Courts Act 1912 and certain other Acts; to amend the Crimes Act 1900 and certain other Acts; and for purposes connected therewith.
This Act may be cited as the District Court Act 1973.
This Act shall commence on such day as may be appointed by the Governor in respect thereof and as may be notified by proclamation published in the Gazette.
[s 3 rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 8]
In this Act, except in so far as the context or subject-matter otherwise indicates or requires—
means action in the Court, but does not include any proceedings under Division 8 of Part III or under Part IV ;

in relation to an action, means set-off admitted by the plaintiff in the document lodged by the plaintiff to commence the action or, where a defendant pleads a cross-claim, by the defendant in the prescribed notice of the cross-claim;
[def am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2 ; Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
[def rep Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3[3.8] , effective 4 December 2006]
means Chief Judge of the Court;
[def insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
means proceedings in the Court in its civil jurisdiction;
[def insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
includes any body of persons that may by law sue or be sued, whether in its own name or in the name of any officer or other person;
[def insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
means proceedings in the Court in its criminal jurisdiction;
[def insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
in relation to any proceedings, means lodge with the registrar for the proper place in relation to the proceedings, for inclusion in the record of the Court;
means Judge of the Court;
in relation to an action, means judgment given or entered up in the action;
of the Court means $750,000.
[def insrt Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]

includes messuages, tenements and hereditaments, corporeal and incorporeal, of any tenure or description, and whatever may be the estate or interest therein, whether vested or contingent, whether freehold or leasehold, and whether at law or in equity;
[def rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 8]

means a claim for damages arising from death of, or injury to, a person where the death or injury has been caused by an act or omission of the owner or driver of a motor vehicle in the use or operation of the vehicle.
[def subst Act 141 of 1997 s 2 and Sch 1]
in relation to a corporation, includes a director and any person having (whether alone or with others) powers of management, direction or control of the corporation;
[def rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
means prescribed by this Act or the rules;
means the registrar for Sydney.
[def insrt Act 68 of 2004 s 3 and Sch 7, effective 6 July 2004]
where occurring in a provision of Part III and in subsections (3) and (5) , means civil proceedings;
where occurring in a provision of Part IV , means criminal proceedings; and
where occurring in any other provision of this Act, shall be construed according to the context in which the expression occurs;
[def subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
[def subst Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1]
in relation to any proceedings in the Court in its civil jurisdiction—
where there has been no change of venue in respect of the proceedings — means the proclaimed place at which the proceedings were commenced;
where there has been only one change of venue in respect of the proceedings — means the proclaimed place to which the venue was changed; or
where there have been two or more changes of venue in respect of the proceedings — means the proclaimed place to which the venue was last changed;
in relation to a proclaimed place, means the office of the registrar for the proclaimed place;
[def insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 1]
[def rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
means:
any proclaimed place, and
in relation to the Court’s civil jurisdiction — any place (other than a proclaimed place) that is the subject of a direction in force under section 32(1) , and
in relation to the Court’s criminal jurisdiction — any place (other than a proclaimed place) that is the subject of a direction in force under section 173(1) .
[def insrt Act 71 of 2003 s 3 and Sch 3, effective 1 January 2004]
[def rep Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3[3.8] , effective 4 December 2006]
[def rep Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

defterm.emph: the Court or the District Court

p.text: means the District Court of New South Wales, and includes all registries and offices of the Court, whether they are within the precincts of the Court or not;
[def subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

in relation to any proceedings, means the registrar for the proper place in relation to the proceedings, and, where any other registrar is authorised by or under this Act to exercise or discharge any power, authority, duty or function of the registrar for that place, includes that other registrar when exercising or discharging that power, authority, duty or function;
[def subst Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
means—
where occurring in Part 3 and Division 2 of Part 6 , the civil procedure rules; and
[def insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
means a claim for an award of damages to which Division 3 (Modified common law damages) of Part 5 of the Workers Compensation Act 1987 applies.
[def insrt Act 94 of 2001 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 January 2002]
[def rep Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]
[def rep Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]
A reference in this Act—

to the giving of a judgment is a reference to the recording and delivering of a judgment, not being a judgment under any provision of the civil procedure rules prescribed for the purposes of this paragraph; and
to the entering up of a judgment is a reference to the entering up of a judgment in accordance with any provision of the civil procedure rules so prescribed.
[subs (2) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

A reference in this Act to the commencement of proceedings at a proclaimed place (however expressed) is a reference to the commencement of those proceedings by the lodging of the document commencing the proceedings with the registrar for that place.
[subs (3) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
A reference in this Act to the issue of a document at a proclaimed place (however expressed) is a reference to the issue of that document by the registrar for that place.
A reference in this Act to a stay of proceedings (however expressed) includes a reference to a stay of enforcement of the judgment arising from the proceedings.
A reference in this Act to a stay of enforcement of a judgment includes a reference to a stay of the issue of an order or writ under Part 8 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005.
[subs (6) subst Act No 28 of 2005, effective 15 August 2005]

Where a provision of this Act refers to the amount claimed in an action or cross-claim or to the amount for which an action is authorised by this Act to be brought and the action or cross-claim is for the detention of goods, the reference to that amount shall be construed as a reference to an amount equivalent to the value of the goods together with any damages claimed for the detention of the goods.
[subs (7) insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

A reference in this Act to a Court of Quarter Sessions includes a reference to a court which, before 1 July 1973, was a Court of Sessions of the Peace, General Sessions of the Peace, General Sessions, General Quarter Sessions, General or Quarter Sessions, or General and Quarter Sessions.
[subs (8) insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

A reference in this Act to criminal jurisdiction includes a reference to jurisdiction to hear an appeal from any conviction, finding of guilt, sentence or other decision relating to the commission or alleged commission of an offence against the law in force in New South Wales.
[subs (9) insrt Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]
In this Act—
a reference to a function includes a reference to a power, authority and duty; and
a reference to the exercise of a function includes, where the function is a duty, a reference to the performance of the duty.
[subs (10) insrt Act 210 of 1986 s 3 and Sch 1]

A reference in this or any other Act, or in any instrument, to the registrar of the District Court for a proclaimed place is, if there are 2 registrars for that place, a reference to either registrar.
[subs (11) insrt Act 88 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 1]
Notes included in this Act do not form part of this Act.
[subs (12) insrt Act 77 of 2005 s 48 and Sch 6, effective 1 January 2006]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 4.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 Div 8, s 4(1), “action”.
(NSW) Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001 s 65.

By definition in s 4(1) , “action” excludes statutory appeals (Cook v Head [1976] 1 NSWLR 176 at 180, 185 and 187) and criminal proceedings: Grzybowicz v Smiljanic [1980] 1 NSWLR 627 at 630 and proceedings under Pt 3 Div 8 (including certain equitable relief) Pelechowski v Registrar, Court of Appeal (1999) 198 CLR 435 at 448 [39]; 162 ALR 336 at 345; [1999] HCA 19; BC9902072 . It is arguable that the term “action” does not extend to applications for judicial review under s 65 of the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001: Obieta v Consumer, Tenancy and Trading Tribunal (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 249; BC200907371 at [9]–[11] .
The history of Courts of Quarter Sessions is summarised in R v Longshaw (1990) 20 NSWLR 554 at 560 .

The CPA s 3 contains various definitions including “civil proceedings”, “criminal proceedings”, “judgment”, “jurisdictional limit”, “minor”, “motor accident claim”, “officer”, “the rules” and “workplace injury damages claim”. Further definitions are contained in the Dictionary to the UCPR. Section 3 of the CPA defines “uniform rules” rules made, or taken to have been made, under s 9 of the CPA (by the Uniform Rules Committee).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 5] s 5 Interpretation: nearest proclaimed place

p.text: A reference in this Act to the nearest proclaimed place to another place (however expressed) is a reference to the proclaimed place the distance between the principal registry for which and that other place is shorter than the distance between any other principal registry and that other place.
In subsection (1) —
means distance computed in accordance with the civil procedure rules;
in relation to a proclaimed place means—
where there is only one registry for the proclaimed place — that registry; or

where there are two or more registries for the proclaimed place — the registry specified in, or determined in accordance with, the civil procedure rules as being the principal registry for the proclaimed place.
[subs (2) am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

The Governor may, at the Governor's discretion, by proclamation, specify an address or a place at which the principal registry for a proclaimed place shall be deemed to be situated, and that principal registry shall, for the purposes of subsection (1) , be deemed to be situated at the address or place so specified, notwithstanding that it may be situated elsewhere.
[subs (3) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

Where under this Act or the civil or criminal procedure rules the Court may make any order or give any direction or leave or do any other thing on terms, the Court may make the order or give the direction or leave or do the thing on such terms and conditions (if any) as the Court thinks fit.
[s 6 am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 6.5] Extent of power to impose terms

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 6.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 86.

heading.title: Extent of power to impose terms

p.text: CPA s 86 confers a general power to make any order on terms. Both that provision and the present section permit the court to impose “such terms and conditions as the court thinks fit”. However, neither provision permits the court to make an order for the payment of costs in criminal proceedings. Nor do they permit the court to adjourn criminal proceedings, subject to an order for the payment of costs. However, the court may adjourn criminal proceedings on the basis of an agreement between the parties or the acceptance of an undertaking by one of the parties: R v Seebag (CCA(NSW), 16 February 1993, unreported); R v Beeby (1999) 104 A Crim R 142; [1999] NSWCCA 30; BC9900748 ; R v Bucksath (2000) 114 A Crim R 1; [2000] NSWCCA 135; BC200002110 . The court may stay criminal proceedings to give effect to an undertaking by the Crown to pay costs thrown away by reason of an adjournment: R v Bucksath, above,at [31]–[33] ; R v Mosely (1992) 28 NSWLR 735; 65 A Crim R 452; BC9203074 at 740 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 7] s 7 Application of certain provisions of this Act

leg:heading.title: Application of certain provisions of this Act

p.text: The provisions of Part 3 and Division 2 of Part 6 and the civil procedure rules—
apply to and in respect of proceedings in the Court in its civil jurisdiction; and
except as provided by Part 4 , do not apply to or in respect of proceedings in the Court in its criminal jurisdiction.
[s 7 am Act 170 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 2]

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 7.5] Division of civil and criminal jurisdiction

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 Pt 3, Pt 4.

heading.title: Division of civil and criminal jurisdiction

p.text: The powers of the court in its civil jurisdiction under Pt 3 of the Act do not apply to its criminal jurisdiction unless specifically provided in Pt 4 of the Act: R v Mosely (1992) 28 NSWLR 735 at 737 ; Comptroller General of Customs v D'Aquino Brothers Pty Ltd (NSWCCA, Hunt CJ, Ireland and Dowd JJ, No 60223/95, 19 February 1996, unreported, BC9600606).

level.toc-caption: [DCA s 7.10] Application of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCA s 7.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 10(1).

heading.title: Application of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules

p.text: The rules of court are taken to include the uniform rules to the extent to which they are applicable in the District Court: s 10(1) of the CPA.
